comments.content:
Create a gateway load balancer.
Deploy the NVAs.
Link NIC1 to the load balancer.

discussion.content:
Provided answer is wrong according to this:
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/load-balancer/tutorial-gateway-portal

Correct answer is:
1. Create a gateway Load balancer
2. Deploy the NVAs
3. Link NIC1 to the load balancer (Chain virtual machine to Gateway Load Balancer)

comments.content:
I was wrong! Correct answers are:
1. Create a gateway Load balancer 2. Deploy the NVAs 3. Link NIC1 to the load balancer

discussion.content:
1. Create a standard public load balancer.
2. Create a gateway load balancer.
3. Deploy the NVAs.

(Note: Assigning PIP1 to the load balancer and linking NIC1 to the load balancer will happen as part of configuring the load balancer setup after the NVA deployment.)

Selected Answer: A
Create a Gateway load balancer OK
Link the NIC1 to the load balancer = (this is not possible, you can assign a whole subnet or a Static IP only) but this is the only answer that makes sense as second step anyway.
Deploy the VNAs = seems correct 
check the tutorial here below and tell me your opinions lads...come on keep pushing and happy new 2025.... Hopefully we'll get there soon. :-) 
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/load-balancer/tutorial-gateway-portal

comments.content: Based on the info in the provided link, it does not matter if you deploy NVAs before all or later. Also, you can configure LB and link an IP at the final stage

questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP
-

You have an Azure subscription that contains a virtual machine named VM1. VM1 contains a NIC named NIC1 and a public IP address named PIP1. PIP1 is assigned to NIC1.

You plan to deploy four Network Virtual Appliances (NVAs).

You need to ensure that all the inbound traffic from the internet to PIP1 is inspected by the NVAs. The solution must ensure that the NVA deployment is highly available.

Which three actions should you perform in sequence? To answer, move the appropriate actions from the list of actions to the answer area and arrange them in the correct order.

//IMG//

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
answer is correct
1 ASG for the web servers: This will include all web servers in VNet1.
1 ASG for the database servers: This will include all database servers in VNet2.

Selected Answer: B
2 application security group

comments.content: overall correct, but worth remembering you may have multiple ASGs in one subnet of a VNET

Answer is correct but your explanation is incorrect. In fact, you can have multiple Application Security Groups (ASGs) within a single Virtual Network (VNet), and you can use ASGs to group virtual machines (VMs) or other network interfaces (NICs) across multiple VNets.

You need 2 ASG groups because 
1 ASG for the web servers: This will include all web servers in VNet1.
1 ASG for the database servers: This will include all database servers in VNet2.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
ASG is restricted one per Vnet. for two Vnets you need two ASGs minimum.

questions.question_text:
You have two Azure virtual networks named VNet1 and VNet2 that are peered with each other. VNet1 hosts 10 virtual machines that contain web servers. VNet2 hosts five virtual machines that contain database servers.

You need to configure a security solution that meets the following requirements:

• Ensures that the database servers can accept connections only from the web servers
• Ensures that the web servers can initiate connections only to the database servers
• Ensures that all network security groups (NSGs) are associated only with subnets
• Use application security groups to implement the solution

What is the minimum number of application security groups required?

comments.content:

Answer given is correct

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT
-

You have an Azure subscription that contains six Azure App Service apps. The apps have an identical configuration and are deployed across multiple Azure regions.

You plan to deploy Azure Front Door to load balance traffic across the apps.

You need to ensure that the round robin load-balancing algorithm will send traffic only to a limited number App Service apps based on their proximity to a user. The solution must minimize administrative effort.

What should you modify, and what should you configure? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.

NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

//IMG//

discussion.content:
Look for any routing rule with an exact match on the Path
If no exact match Paths, look for routing rules with a wildcard Path that matches
If no routing rules are found with a matching Path, then reject the request and return a 400: Bad Request error HTTP response.

comments.content: Great explanation. to complete it I would add " if more than one rule with wildcard Paths matches, use the most specific (detailed) path matched.

discussion.content: Longest match is the correct answer.

Answer is correct
looks for exact match IF NOT then Wildcard path match otherwise Bad request
This question was on the exam on 18th Feb 2022.
